subhead: Massacres, which have been filmed and shared on social media, have taken place in the capital of North Darfur since the city was seized by the Rapid Support Forces, led by General Mohammed Hamdan Dagalo.

subhead: Militants have so far returned the remains of 17 of the 28 deceased hostages that Hamas had agreed to hand over as part of a United States-brokered truce deal with Israel.

title: 'Argentina gradually joins the great authoritarian wave sweeping the globe'
subhead: In an op-ed for Le Monde, political scientist David Copello and historian Olivier Compagnon write that commentators' economic focus should not obscure the institutional changes underway after Milei's victory in the legislative elections.

title: Over 1,000 items looted in California museum heist
subhead: Stolen items include neckpieces by the late artist and metalsmith Florence Resnikoff, a pair of scrimshaw walrus tusks and Native American baskets. The burglary occurred in the early morning hours of Oct. 15 at an off-site storage facility of the Oakland Museum of California, Oakland Police said.

title: 'Airbnb has shaped the idea that everything can be monetized. It's a logic of constant optimization'
subhead: 'The Airbnb Ogre' (2/6). In Paris, about one-third of the listings available on Airbnb have been removed from the 'permanent' housing market, which contributes to the housing crisis in the French capital, explains researcher Jeanne Richon in an interview with Le Monde.

How Airbnb made France its favorite destination, with more than one million listings
subhead: 'The Airbnb Ogre' (1/6). In 15 years, the platform has established itself in France, the leading tourist destination, thanks to effective lobbying and favorable tax conditions. It has even worsened the housing crisis. The company is now expanding its offerings to continue its growth.

title: Too old to get a job, too young to retire: The French women over 50 stuck in limbo
subhead: In France, 21% of people aged 55-61 struggle to find work but are unable to retire. Women, who suffer more from societal inequalities throughout their career, are particularly at risk.

title: 'We're buying time, but we won't win the fight': Senegal's Saint-Louis faces the inexorable rise of the sea
subhead: 'Our planet at +1.5°C' (3/6). Senegal's historic city will be largely underwater by the end of the 21st century. Several thousand fishermen have already left their homes on the beach for a stifling dormitory town.
